data.title: When word wrap is disabled text still wraps until word wrap is toggled on and off again

milestone.title: Backlog
milestone.description: Work not yet planned for a specific release.

data.body:
- VSCode Version: Code - Insiders 1.3.0-insider (5474147bb83618975409dad7d8aa96151d7d1ea1, 2016-06-21T19:35:37.900Z)
- OS Version: Windows_NT ia32 10.0.14342

Steps to Reproduce:
1. Open VS Code
2. Ensure that word wrap is already not set (otherwise set it and reopen VS Code)*
3. Paste a large amount of text (over 300 columns long)
4. Observe that the text DID wrap at some arbitrary length (at some word break near 300 columns)

\* It seems to do the right thing if word wrap is turned off _after_ the text is pasted.

![image](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/494055/16250357/9452d1ec-37d1-11e6-9622-fe6bcf6ef7f0.png)

Workaround seems to be to toggle word wrap and then things work correctly.

![image](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/494055/16250426/266a3822-37d2-11e6-804e-07786cd16f2a.png)

data.title: An option to disable current line highlight.
data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.2.1
- OS Version: Win 10

There should be an option to disable current line highlight. Sublime has it. I find it quite distracting. 

There are other closed issues on this with no real explanation why.

![Current line highlighting](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/3441158/16246080/51d80bb6-3821-11e6-81f2-78829d4570c3.png)

data.title: Debugging hangs for a powershell script containing git commands.
data.body:
- VSCode Version:
- OS Version:

Steps to Reproduce:
1. Create a script with "git clone" in it, my script is below:

`Write-Host "Start Git Test";

$result = git clone <git repo> "$PSScriptRoot\test.git" 2>&1;

Write-Host "Finished Git Command";
Write-Host $result;`

please note that the <git repo> I am attempting to clone is a local bare repository on my hard drive, so no credentials are needed.
2. Debug the script
3. At this point, for me, the script hangs, the only way I can get it to finish is to pause it, wait a minute, then it will go to the next line, and I can either step through or continue to the end.  I have attached the error displayed on the console in the developer's tools.

If I run the same script from powershell it does not hang, but completes fine.

data.title: Fix endLine parameter in problem matchers
data.body:
If the endLine parameter in a problem matcher is different from startLine then only the first character is underlined in the editor. 

Example compiler message:
`main.rs:1:1: 3:2 warning: function is never used: foo, #[warn(dead_code)] on by default`

With the regex:
`"^(.+?):(\\d+):(\\d+):\\s+(\\d+):(\\d+)\\s+(\\w+):\\s+(.+)$"`

Results in:
![screen shot 2016-06-21 at 6 14 54 pm](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/5770094/16248321/7c6df362-37dc-11e6-8e40-0860c09e2614.png)

marker.endLineNumber is being incorrectly set to location.startLineNumber in getMarkerMatch

data.title: Add files to Recent Files list when brought in via DND
data.body:
- VSCode Version: Code - Insiders 1.3.0-insider (06d108b4a0aa6c031e7c1e61a463c069809d6019, 2016-06-21T17:55:32.931Z)
- OS Version: Windows_NT ia32 10.0.14342

Steps to Reproduce:
1. Open VS Code
2. Open some files by DND from file browser onto VS Code
3. Close VS Code
4. Try to use File > Open Recent > ...
5. Observe that the files that had been opened recently are not in this list.

![image](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/494055/16242973/e0e6d602-37a9-11e6-84a8-10171cf1fd64.png)

Maybe I misunderstood this menu but I expected there would be a list of files that had been opened recently, in the same way that Notepad++ does.

![image](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/494055/16243037/3b366c94-37aa-11e6-8155-f95cad250ff1.png)

Would be nice if this list was also preserved across updates of VS Code.

data.title: Array.concat
data.body:
it can actually take both items and arrays

EcmaScript Language Specefication says:
http://www.ecma-international.org/ecma-262/7.0/index.html#sec-array.prototype.concat

When the concat method is called with zero or more arguments, it returns an array containing the array elements of the object followed by the array elements of each argument in order.

data.title: Close panel 'x' button should be a minimize button '_'
data.body: It's particularly confusing with the terminal panel, a `x` is ambiguous whether it will kill the terminal process when really this is purely a minimize button `_` for all panels.

data.title: (Nightly) Lose ability to open side panel after opening an extension from the new extensions panel
data.body:
- VSCode Version: `Version 1.3.0-insider (1.3.0-insider)` 06d108b4a0aa6c031e7c1e61a463c069809d6019
- OS Version: `OS X El Capitan 10.11.5`

Steps to Reproduce:
1. Open the extension panel and click on one of the extensions
2. Click on the extension button (on the panel) again to hide the panel (or the shortcut key)
3. (BUG) If you try to click on the extension button yet again to reopen the panel it will open but badly (too narrow and can't be resized)
4. The more you do, the more things start going wrong after this point -- editors go missing, panels can go missing, etc

On the bright side the new extension panel looks great and will be great! :)

data.title: OSX: Automatically close (non-project) windows when their last editor is closed
data.body:
On OS X, VSCode can persist without any open windows, and remain perfectly usable through the menu bar / dock icon. (Which is great, since it matches OS X's document-centric UI conventions 100%.)

Because of that, I believe it doesn't make a lot of sense to keep non-project (purple) windows open on OS X without any open editors on them, like on this screenshot: 

![](https://cloudup.com/cE42l-2NmsT+)

For project (blue) windows, keeping them open makes total sense, since the project itself can be seen as a document from the perspective of the document-centric UI.

With this in mind, I'd like to propose that on OS X, whenever you close the last document on a non-project (purple) window, the window itself closes. This behavior would make VS Code consistent with both TextMate and Sublime Text, especially now that you're going to introduce tabs.

Maybe this could be exposed as an option, on by default on OS X. (That way OS X users that want to retain the current behavior can do so, and users of Linux/Windows that want the window closing behavior can also do so.)

data.title: Support `-r` flag when combined with `-w`

milestone.title: Backlog
milestone.description: Work not yet planned for a specific release.

data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.2.1
- OS Version: OS X 10.11.5

Steps to Reproduce:
1. Have an existing VSCode window open
2. Run `code -w -r file.js`
3. Only the `-w` flag gets honored, but not `-r`. (So file opens in a separate window)

In that circumstance `-w` should probably wait for the _editor_ to be closed (and not the window, since that's reused)

data.title: Performance degradation in a few minutes
data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.2.1
- OS Version: OS X 10.11.5

Steps to Reproduce:
1. Open (relatively) large C# Unity project (420 scripts)
2. Work for about 10-15 mins

Hi
Since update 1.2 (still persists in v1.2.1) Visual Studio Code started having performance degradation after a few minutes of working. The Intellisense is fluent and rapid in the first few minutes (< 1second for suggestion) but gradually takes more time to process information (> 60 seconds for suggestion).
I use the legacy C# plugin to work with a Unity project. The most up-to-date C# extension is not installed. I tried various suggestions I found here (i.e. disabling Git, excluding certain folders), but the issue keeps creeping in. I currently quickly kill VSCode and start the project back up to have a fluent intellisense for a few minutes.

Any help or light that can be shed on the matter?

Thank you.

data.title: VSCode never starts the second time
data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.2.1 fe7f407b95b7f78405846188259504b34ef72761
- OS Version: OS X 10.11.5

Steps to Reproduce:
1. Download VSCode
2. Unzip
3. Run (from Finder or Alfred)
4. Quit
5. Run (never opens, crashes on start-up)
   
    6/21/16 9:40:09.385 AM com.apple.xpc.launchd[1]: (com.microsoft.VSCode.445792[5119]) Service exited with abnormal code: 1
6. Go back to step 1 and you can run it once.

Interestingly, I can run it from the terminal over and over again.

```
open Visual\ Studio\ Code.app
```

I had it in ~/Applications and thought that might be the issue, but after moving it to /Applications, I get the same behavior. It's happened I think for a couple versions. I only run it once every 2 weeks or so. Also, if it helps, I have had my laptop crash while VSCode was opened in case you can think of any kind of corrupted application state data that might do this.

My guess is something to do with my .bash_profile.

data.title: Support for Emmet preferences and syntaxProfiles
Added order to snippet tab stops
data.body:
Currently when tabbing through snippets you get the order each tab-stop/id is parsed. I've tried to improve on this with the following criterias:
- Id's are sorted first with their relative order unchanged (e.g. {id}, {id:label})
- Tab-stops follow id's, and are sorted in ascending order (e.g. "$2 $3 $1" => $1, $2, $3)
- The $0 (or highest tab-stop) will be used as the final placeHolder

I've added a few tests and tested this with various snippets and I think it feels much better. You can now do import snippets in the correct order for IntelliSense!

```
import { $2 } from '${1:module}';$0
```

data.title: [Idea] Cursor animations
data.body:
It would be nice to be able to have various style of cursor animations. As someone who personally wants the smooth cursor animation instead of flat blinking.

Here is the fiddle I made: https://jsfiddle.net/rxercv6v/
And here is the preview of that fiddle:

![cursor](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/1087399/16227353/49e62006-37da-11e6-95b5-80dac0863d11.gif)

In the above gif
- `blink` on 3rd line
- `smooth` on 4th line
- `phase` on 5th line
- `expand` on 6th line
- `solid` on 7th line

data.title: problemMatcher vs zero-based column values

milestone.title: On Deck
milestone.description:
The Issues assigned to the **On Deck** milestone under consideration for the upcoming milestones.
Our goal is to always have less than 100 Issues on deck.

data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.2.1
- OS Version: Windows 10

I'm trying to parse error messages of OCaml compiler like this:

```
File "test.ml", line 1, characters 0-1:
Error: Syntax error
```

with a a following problemMatcher:

```
"problemMatcher": {
    "owner": "ocaml",
    "fileLocation": ["relative", "${fileDirname}"],
    "pattern": [
        {
            "regexp": "^File \"(.*)\", line (\\d+), characters (\\d+)-(\\d+):$",
            "file": 1,
            "line": 2,
            "column": 3,
            "endColumn": 4
        },
        {
            "regexp": "^(Warning|Error):\\s+(.*)$",
            "severity": 1
            "message": 2
        }
    ]
}
```

Column range of error (characters 0-1) is zero-based while VS Code expects that column numbers starts from one; so I have an error marker in VS Code shifted one position to left

Is it possible to add additional problemMatcher property to correctly handle this case?

data.title: Editor hover is easily lost in editor content
data.body:
I am not a big fan of our hover when it has lots of contents because the content blends too easy into the other contents of the editor making it hard to read.

![image](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/900690/16224554/c9e51f4c-37a2-11e6-8c17-06b18d24fc45.png)

At the minimum the hover should have a different background color. Also in this example the JS doc comments look very similar to the actual method signature. I would love if both could be made more distinct so that its clear the one is documentation and the other is signature.

/cc @joaomoreno @bgashler1 @stevencl @alexandrudima

data.title: Crash/not responding after Filesearch in big Project
data.body:
Every Time I use the file search (F1 -> enter Filename) the Editor starts lagging and stop responding a while later (maybe half an hour, sometimes longer) and forces me to restart after "not responding"-message.
- VSCode Version: 1.2.1 
- OS Version: Win10 
- current Project: ~148.000 Files,  ~25.000 Folders

Steps to Reproduce:
1. "Open Folder" of big Project
2. Search for files and open them (F1)
3. after a longer Time (upwards of 15min) window stops responding

data.title: Setting variable value results in a changed value highlight on next step
data.body:
Steps to Reproduce:
-  use this snippet:
  
  ``` js
  var x = "foo";
  
  debugger;
  debugger;
  ```
- start debugging: debugger stops on first 'debugger' statement
- change the value of x to "bar": after closing the edit box the new value is shown
- step once

Notice: the value "bar" is shown as changed even if it has not.

The correct behaviour would be to highlight the value on dismissing the edit box (and if the new value is really different from the old).
